page.title: 02RHUM EXCAVATION_INTRODUCTION
page.content:
In the summer of 1983 the Nature Conservancy Council uncovered a scatter of flaked stones whilst ploughing one of the fields to the north of Kinloch on Rhum. This suggested that there might be evidence surviving from some of the early inhabitants so in 1984 a team was organised from the National Museum of Antiquities of Scotland, financed by the Scottish Development Department, to examine the surviving remains.
The first season of work established that in one area of the field there were indeed the remains of the tools used and the pits dug by the early inhabitants. During April / May 1985 further excavations took place to look at the site in more detail.
